page_analysis.text_content:
Basements
&
Excavated
features

Floor area regulations
are intended to address
the building mass and
the appearance of the
streetscape. Therefore,
if basement area is
below grade and does
not contribute to the
apparent mass of a
building, that area,
even if it is habitable,
need not be included in
the total floor area.

Code sections
Page 40
18.12.090 (a, b, & c)
Page 41
18.12.090 (c)
Page 43
18.12.090 (c) (1)
Page 44
18.12.090 (c) (2)

40

Basement standards

• May not be located in special flood hazard areas.
• May not extend beyond building footprint.
• May not encroach into required yards, except where
  main dwelling is permitted to extend into rear yard.

FAR
Basements (even habitable ones) do
not count as floor area if first floor
is no more than 3' above grade.

Fig 35 Basement & grade

Excavated features

There are two types of excavated features:
• Light wells and stairwells
• Below-grade patios

FAR
Excavation will not affect grade or
measurement of floor area if stan-
dards are met (see pages 42 and 43).

Fig 36 Excavated feature & grade

A: distance between top of first floor
and grade if excavation meets the
size/dimensioinal limits described in
Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.

B: distance between top of first
floor and grade if excavated
features exceed the
size/dimensioinal limits described
in Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.

Top of first floor

Basement

Excavated
feature

Grade if excavated features
meet standards described in
Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.

Grade if excavated features
exceed standards described in
Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.

visual_elements.description: Titled 'Fig 35 Basement & grade', this is a simple line drawing showing a cross-section of the ground, represented by a horizontal line with hatch marks below it, indicating the grade level. It is located below the 'Basement standards' section.

Titled 'Fig 36 Excavated feature & grade', this is a detailed cross-section diagram showing a portion of a building's foundation and an adjacent excavated area. It illustrates:
- A vertical section labeled 'Basement'.
- An adjacent, lower section labeled 'Excavated feature'.
- A horizontal line labeled 'Top of first floor' above the ground level.
- Two different grade levels are shown. The higher grade, labeled 'Grade if excavated features meet standards...', is at the level of the top of the excavated feature. The lower grade, labeled 'Grade if excavated features exceed standards...', is at the bottom of the excavated feature.
- A double-headed arrow labeled 'A' measures the vertical distance from the 'Top of first floor' to the higher grade line.
- A double-headed arrow labeled 'B' measures the vertical distance from the 'Top of first floor' to the lower grade line.
- The ground is indicated with cross-hatching.
visual_elements.location: Right side of the page, from middle to bottom

visual_elements.description: A dark grey vertical bar on the left side of the page containing the main heading 'Basements & Excavated features', an introductory paragraph, and a list of 'Code sections'.
A light grey box under the 'Basement standards' section, with the heading 'FAR', containing a rule about basements and floor area.
A light grey box under the 'Excavated features' section, with the heading 'FAR', containing a rule about how excavation affects grade and floor area.

additional_notes: The page has a two-column layout. The left column is a dark grey sidebar, and the main content is in the wider right column.
The page number '40' is located at the bottom left corner, within the grey sidebar.
The image is a clean digital graphic, not a scanned photocopy; there are no handwritten annotations, stamps, or quality degradation.
